Experiences: Artificiality Institute (Co-Founder): The Artificiality Institute guides humanity through its most profound transformation yet‚Äîliving alongside synthetic intelligence. As a beacon of hope for human flourishing in a synthetic world, we illuminate the human journey into a future where identities blend, cognition extends beyond biology, and meaningful symbiosis with synthetic minds becomes reality.      Through research, education, and dialogue, we shape a future where human and synthetic minds do more than coexist‚Äîthey co-create. In this shared evolution, we extend the meaning of being human through story, relationship, and systems rooted in lived experience.     Originally founded in 2019, Artificiality was re-established in 2025 as a nonprofit research institute dedicated to shaping the human experience in a synthetic world. We are currently awaiting 501(c)(3) status.     Our Mission and Vision  - Mission: To shape the emerging human experience in an increasingly synthetic world through story-based research, immersive education, and cultural dialogue.  - Vision: A world where human identity is enriched by awe of diverse intelligences, wonder at emergent consciousness, and symbiosis with minds created for our minds.     Our Core Activities:  - The Artificiality Summit: Our annual, immersive, and intimate gathering that explores the human experience of AI. Join us in Bend Oregon in October.   - The Chronicle: Our longitudinal story-gathering project that captures the often-unseen moments where human lives are changed by synthetic intelligences. Join us in co-creating a cultural dataset to help make AI systems for all of us.   - Futures Program: For organizations, we use our Chronicle research as a cultural foresight tool to see the future use of AI and how that changes cultures. Our current research areas are (aka what interests me on LinkedIn as well):      - Intimacy: Exploring how intimacy, not attention, becomes the driving force in human-AI interactions and how deeply personalized AI connections reshape relationships, going beyond superficial engagement to foster meaningful human-AI bonds.  - Spatiality: Examining how spatial and embodied intelligence alters human cognition and abstract reasoning, with implications for problem-solving and collaboration.  - Consciousness: Rethinking consciousness by examining the distinction between biological and synthetic awareness, and the moral questions that arise as synthetic forms emerge.  - Knowledge: Understanding the consequences of the "knowledge-ome"‚Äîa planetary-scale system where AI, human intelligence, and ecosystems of information can reshape our understanding of knowledge itself.  - Minds: Exploring AI as more than a tool, considering it as a ‚Äúmind" capable of augmenting and expanding human creativity, emotional depth, and strategic thinking. We run workshops in conjunction with the Machine Intelligence Research Institute for recruiting talented computer scientists and mathematicians, helping those who are a good fit transition towards working on technical AI safety.      CFAR also runs a mainline workshop to which anyone can apply, where we teach many of the tools we've developed, and help people think clearly about the problems and opportunities in their life. There are ~15000 alumni of the mainline workshop, and many of those have continued to engage with the broader EA and rationality community. The mainline workshop is an important anchor of the epistemic culture around MIRI, and some parts of AI safety.     I teach at, and have developed curriculum for, all of CFAR's main programs including the mainline workshop, MSFP, and AIRCS. I also designed and led CFAR's 2019 instructor training.     In addition to workshops, I have done work on rationality development, specializing in methods for resolving deep disagreements of intuition, and efficient tacit knowledge transfer more generally.     My basic development loop involves:  - Identifying a problem that seems to be bottlenecking progress on some important dimension.   - Exploring the literature (if it exists) and other existing resources that are relevant to this domain and/or generating hypotheses for how to solve or circumvent the core problem.  - Running 2 to 8 person test sessions with volunteers, noticing where and how my intervention is failing, and iteratively trying to patch those problems.  - Deploying those tools, either by teaching the relevant researchers the cognitive skill directly, or by personally facilitating a process for them.     My sense of "what the problem is", and what sorts of interventions seem promising, usually changes drastically over the course of this process. | Survival and Flourishing Fund (Grant Evaluator): The Survival and Flourishing Fund is a Donor Advised Fund held at the Silicon Valley Community Foundation, funded by Jaan Tallinn. I filled a variety of roles for BERI as the organization was growing, including:  - Interviewing, hiring, and onboarding contractors for several roles supporting researchers at academic x-risk focused orgs.  - Basic legal research  - Organizing and managing events  - Creating an open-use list of prediction market questions on AI outcomes.  - Evaluating grant applications, and making recommendations to the grants committee. | Center for Decision Research, Booth School of Business, University of Chicago (Research Assistant): Data collection and data coding of consumer behavior experiments. | Ben Radford (Paranormal Research and Investigation Intern): [Note: I no longer believe extra-physical psychic phenomena exist, and I am confident enough in this view that I don't think investigating parapsychology is very interesting or informative, in most cases.]     Once upon a time, I was seriously interested in parapsychology, psychic phenomena, and the content of "new-age" beliefs. I spent much of my teenage years pursuing this fascination and trying to develop my own psychic faculties. My work with Ben is largely research, tracking down sources and tracing the history of a claim. In this role, she brings decades of experience as a data and AI leader to spearhead centralized functions for responsible AI and governance. Prior to her role at HCLTech, she was Global Leader of Responsible AI Initiatives at IBM and was instrumental in developing and executing foundational practices in AI ethics and governance, including building IBM's Ethics by Design program and its Algorithmic Impact Assessment.

She has been recognized as one of the 100 Brilliant Women in AI Ethics and has been influential in shaping responsible AI and governance practices within the technology industry as a whole. She has served as Associate Director of the Notre Dame - IBM Tech Ethics Lab. She also helped craft the IAPP AI Governance Professional Body of Knowledge and its associated certification exam and now serves as co-chair of the advisory board for the AI Governance Professional certification exam development board. As a World Economic Forum Fellow, she provided executive and research leadership on research centered on Generative AI.

Dr. Domin holds a Ph.D. in Business Analytics and Data Science and has professional certifications in AI Governance and multiple project management methodologies. These include the AI Governance Professional (AIGP), Project Management Professional (PMP), PMI-Agile Certified Practitioner (PMI-ACP), and Certified Scrum Master (CSM) certifications.

She has also provided leadership and made contributions to working groups such as the US AI Safety Institute Consortium Working Group, World Economic Forum AI Governance Alliance Responsible Applications and Transformation Working Group, XPRIZE Deep Tech Brain Trust, Data & Trust Alliance User Group for the Algorithmic Bias Safeguards for Workforce, NIST Generative AI Public Working Group, Ohio State University Program on Data and Governance's Expert Group on Responsible AI Management, and various IBM Open Innovation Community initiatives.

Deeply committed to advancing responsible technology, Dr. Domin writes and speaks about the topic across a diverse array of platforms and venues around the globe.

AA @ Cochise College | History ‚Äì Bachelor of Arts - BA @ University of Maryland Global Campus || Summary: Jeremy Kofsky is a strategic advisor, intelligence operations specialist, keynote speaker, published author, and advocate for tactical innovation who is the mastermind behind organizations charged with the vital undertakings of intelligence and global security operations.     Jeremy's journey of innovation began during his time in the Marine Corps' leading edge as a point man directing patrols during the darkest days of the Iraq War. He realized the traditional 'kick in doors' approach was not the most effective way forward and decided to dedicate himself to better understanding humans. Through his accumulated experience, education, and professional contacts, Jeremy has helped optimize several aspects of Marine Corps operations and has become a sought-after innovation expert at the senior and executive levels for some of the Marine Corps' most challenging issues.     Jeremy's background over the past two decades has centered on building organizations and units aligned with his mission of helping people realize their full potential. In his mid-20s, he served as a senior intelligence advisor for various high-level projects understanding human behavioral patterns worldwide. He later transitioned this experience into becoming a civil-military operational planner and a Red Team leader, codifying him as an innovative planner and thinker within the military.      Jeremy shares his lessons learned while creating, managing, and optimizing processes with organizations and individuals all over the world. Jeremy has sought to further his knowledge base in support of his outlook, resulting in recognition as a Brute Krulak Scholar for Innovation, the only enlisted member selected in the program‚Äôs history, and the recipient of the 2023 Expeditionary Warfare Excellence Award. Additionally, he holds two Masters Degrees, one in Strategic Intelligence and another in Public Policy and Administration.     Jeremy‚Äôs post-graduate education includes a Machine Learning Specialization from Stanford University and a 2ndLt J.P. Blecksmith Senior Research Fellowship for Artificial Intelligence with the Key Terrain Cyber Institute. Jeremy serves as the Managing Editor for Lethal Minds Journal, a professional journal empowering the voice of warfighters to shape the future of defense. Jeremy has been published in several professional journals, focusing on optimizing strategies for future conflicts and innovations, notably the rise of Artificial Intelligence in military applications. He has also been a featured presenter and panelist for the Marine Corps, the tech industry, and consulting forums.

I never studied them in college, I studied Civil Engineering instead. But during college, I gradually shifted my focus from Civil Engineering to AI. It affected my grades a lot, but I don‚Äôt regret it. I chose the right path. I still appreciate my Civil Engineering background. Someone once said something about connecting the dots I don't know if it was Steve Jobs or Elon Musk but I can say for sure: those engineering classes gave me a strong mathematical foundation that made learning and understanding AI much easier. This journey hasn't been easy. It's been full of moments of joy and laughter, but also failure. I‚Äôve failed in two startups, but honestly, I consider startup life a school of thought on its own. Despite the setbacks, my passion for AI has never faded in fact, it‚Äôs only deepened.     Today, I‚Äôm a graduate student at WorldQuant University, pursuing a Master of Science in Financial Engineering, a path that combines my love for math, AI, and problem-solving in real-world systems.  I‚Äôm particularly passionate about how AI can uplift the less privileged, and I advocate for explainable, ethical, and responsible AI. My work is rooted in research, and it's through research that I‚Äôve learned  the most. Being African, I‚Äôve also observed how underrepresented we are in the global AI conversation. We‚Äôre often seen only as consumers, not creators. That needs to change. I‚Äôve written on topics like balancing innovation and regulation, because overregulation can stifle progress especially, in places like  Africa where the ecosystem is just beginning to grow.     Currently, I work at MsingiAI, a research lab focused on democratizing AI access in Africa. All of our work is open source. I‚Äôve been championing Open Source AI development in Africa, because I believe it‚Äôs the key to wider adoption, inclusion, and innovation across the continent. I don‚Äôt know exactly where this path will take me, but I‚Äôm optimistic. I love talking about AI, startups, and the African tech landscape. If you're into any of that, feel free to reach out via LinkedIn or email. I‚Äôve got a lot to say probably enough for a book but for now, let me keep it short.     Cheers,  Korir

Experiences: International Association for Safe & Ethical AI (Interim Executive Director): The International Association for Safe and Ethical AI (IASEAI) is a non-profit organization founded to address the risks and opportunities associated with rapid advances in AI.     Our mission is to ensure that AI systems are guaranteed to operate safely and ethically; and to shape policy, promote research, and build understanding and community around this goal.     As AI systems become more capable and more directly involved in critical social and economic functions, it is essential to provide assurances that they will operate safely and benefit those affected. Policy innovations should encourage the development of AI systems that can support such assurances, with support from the AI research community. IASEAI will provide a unified voice for the many individuals, research groups, and organizations that share these goals and will help to create a global community to achieve them.     As Interim Executive Director I have overall responsibility to establish the entity, launch initial operations (recruit startup team, hire vendors, build initial membership, run inaugural conference, establish long-term structure, function, and funding to scale), and to oversee the recruitment of officers, and the election of council members and leadership for the long term. | Center for Human-Compatible AI (Executive Director): Founded in late 2016, the UC Berkeley Center for Human-Compatible Artificial Intelligence (CHAI) aims to reorient the field of AI towards creating systems that are provably safe and beneficial to humans. As the Executive Director, Mark‚Äôs objectives are to oversee the center's operations and strategic direction, and to amplify its impact through supervising the direction of research and advising governments, supranational bodies, and corporations on policy implications of technology. Since heading CHAI, Mark has focused on expanding the institute‚Äôs focus toward social and political discourses on AI by engaging an array of experts in areas ranging from philosophy to law. | Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (Advisor - Outreach): The Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) Lab brings together UC Berkeley researchers across computer vision, machine learning, natural language processing, planning, control, and robotics, to pursue fundamental advances in multimodal deep learning, human-compatible AI, and to connect AI with other scientific disciplines and the humanities. As Head of Strategic Outreach, Mark hosts delegations from governments and other institutions to discuss AI research needs, AI policy and R&D, public-private AI partnerships, and the future of AI Governance. | Akvo (Co-Founder and Director): Akvo is a data consultancy and digital platform working to improve outcomes of international development projects in water, sanitation, agriculture, health, energy, education and the environment. As founding member, Mark stewarded growth from inception to today‚Äôs 90 partnerships, 60 staff in 14 countries, and 5 hub office locations worldwide. Mark Founded and chairs the U.S. ‚Äúfriends-of‚Äù organization, Akvo Foundation USA. | DMAI (Co-Founder and Director): DM.AI is an educational AI company, whose vision is to broaden access to quality education by developing cognitive AI assistants and platforms that make personal connections to individuals. All opinions are my own, yay!  --  I want to live in a world where human progress means progress for all humans and sentient beings, not just those who can afford it. We're currently developing technology faster than we can humanly keep up with. The reality is that technology might usher in our next evolutionary leap or entrench existing inequalities forever.     My work, interests, and passions include: human flourishing, AI safety, long-term futures, AGI, AI ethics, and AI welfare. fueled my passion for renewable energy. I knew the difference a PV system and storage solution could make in my household.     When I had the opportunity to study abroad, I chose Appalachian State University for two reasons: they have the oldest renewable energy engineering and sustainable development program in the country, and they have a cycling team. This choice also ignited my other passions‚Äîhealth, fitness, and wellness. Additionally, Boone, NC, is one of the most beautiful mountain towns in the US. Those who have been there will agree.     At my core, I‚Äôm a problem solver. I believe no problem exists without a solution, and I love the challenge of finding solutions to audacious problems. Because of this, I‚Äôm also a solution architect. Big problems always have multiple moving parts, and solving difficult challenges has made me a highly structured, organized, and data-driven individual.     All of this made me very effective in my previous roles in sales and marketing, operations, engineering, design and installation, communication, business, product, and project development.     It also led me to co-found three organizations‚Äîtwo in renewable energy and one in health, fitness, and wellness. In all the organizations I led, we chose to create bold and exciting new products, services, and solutions rather than copying existing ones to make a quick buck. We engaged with potential users and stakeholders before creating a prototype of the solutions we eventually launched. Building something from nothing while working with an equally passionate cross-functional team provides the greatest highs for me.     I am currently looking for big, hairy problems to solve, preferably in the energy space, but I am open to challenges in the health, fitness, and wellness sectors as well.     I enjoy meeting new people and hearing new perspectives. Reach out if you want to talk to me about the above sectors or cycling.

I'm applying multi-agent reinforcement learning to AI Safety. I want to ensure that Artificial Intelligence will benefit human society rather than hurt it. I'm addressing both short-term consequences of existing AI tools such as LLMs and long-term existential risk imposed by the potential development of Artificial General Intelligence.     I propose to solve the problem of AI Safety by improving the social behavior of AI agents. Most AI research is focused on getting AI agents to solve bigger and more complex problems in the most efficient way possible; my research is focused on achieving cooperation, reciprocity and teamwork between AI agents.     My strategy is to distill lessons from the study of animal and human societies and apply them to AI agents.     Read more about my research here: https://r.rachum.com

The aim of the BNVKI is to stimulate research on, and the application and education of Artificial Intelligence (AI), as well as the dissemination of knowledge about AI.     BNVKI was founded in 1981, as the NVKI, by 19 enthousiastic AI-researchers. After an energetic start and a short sleep, the association took new initiatives in 1987. In 1998, the Dutch and the Belgian AI Associations merged, and the association was renamed to BNVKI-AIABN. In 2008, the association welcomed Luxembourg as the third of the Benelux nations, and renamed itself ‚ÄúBNVKI-AIABN: Benelux Association for Artificial Intelligence‚Äù. Since 2002 (Utrecht), the BNVKI endorses BNAIS, a yearly symposium for (Bachelor and Master-level) AI students.     The BNVKI organises the annual BNAIC conference, publishes a quarterly newsletter and sponsors several AI-related events in the Benelux.     BNVKI is a member organisation of the European Association for Artificial Intelligence "     More information see: the BNVKI website http://www.bnvki.org | Ume√• University (Visiting Scholar): | GAIPS Lab (Visiting Scholar): | AI4Belgium (Board Member): Representing Academia in the board of AI4Belgium | BNVKI - BAIAI (Board Member): I'm community builder for Belgium in the Benelux Artificial Intelligence Association.
